That sounds like a great plan! Expanding your garden and trying new fruits and vegetables can be a fun and rewarding experience. And incorporating companion plants is a fantastic way to create a more diverse and resilient garden ecosystem.

Companion planting is a great way to promote healthy soil, reduce pests and diseases, and even improve the flavor and growth of your crops. By choosing the right companions, you can create a mutually beneficial relationship between plants that will enhance the overall health and productivity of your garden.

Some popular companion plants for tomatoes, cucumbers, and carrots include:

* Basil: Repels pests that target tomatoes and improves their flavor
* Marigold: Repels nematodes and other pests that target tomatoes
* Radish: Repels cucumber beetles and improves soil health
* Dill: Repels aphids and other pests that target cucumbers
* Sage: Improves the flavor and growth of carrots
* Nasturtium: Repels aphids, whiteflies, and other pests that target carrots

When selecting companion plants, make sure to choose ones that have similar growing conditions and space requirements to your existing crops. Also, consider the mature size of the companion plants and make sure they won't overshadow or compete with your main crops.

In addition to companion planting, you may also want to consider adding some beneficial insects to your garden, such as ladybugs or lacewings, which can help control pests naturally.

What new fruits and vegetables are you thinking of adding to your garden? Are you looking to grow anything specific, like berries, squash, or leafy greens?
